Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Porous Conductive Polymer Nanostructures as Antistatic Additives for Coatings and Plastics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project aims to continue the development of a family of new nanostructured conductive additives for use in high-performance coatings and composite resins. Static charge buildup from the environment is a critical problem in a number of vehicular applications, which increasingly utilize lightweight components constructed from non-conductive plastic or composite materials. Static charge buildup interferes with electronic components, such as distributed sensors, so that mitigation of this effect is essential for safe vehicle operation. The design of lightweight vehicles using composite materials, which requires high-performing antistatic coatings, will lead to large reductions in fuel consumption and carbon emissions in transportation. In 2011, emissions from transportation accounted for 28% of U.S. greenhouse gas emissions. Modern aircraft designs, utilizing composite materials, show more than 20% reduction in fuel consumption compared to traditional vehicles. Imminent increases in fuel efficiency standards in automobiles will also drive manufacturers to adopt the use of composite materials. The development of the proposed antistatic coatings is essential to enabling these new lightweight material technologies.

The new additives are based on the synthesis of self-assembling nanostructures from conductive polymers and structure-directing agents. When successfully incorporated in commercial paints and primers, the conductive properties of the coating are enhanced without compromising adhesion and durability. In this Phase II effort, we will further optimize these additives, based on key customer requirements, and develop a plan to scale up their production tenfold with reduced waste and production time. Corrosion properties for marine applications will also be evaluated, and the product portfolio will be expanded to address follow-on applications.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project PolyDrop team developed a family of new nanostructured conductive additives for use in high-performance coatings and elastomers. The new additives are based on the synthesis of self-assembling nanostructure from conductive polymers and structure-directing agents. When successfully incorporated in elastomers, the conductive properties of elastomers are enhanced without compromising mechanical properties. In this Phase II effort, we optimized these additives, based on key customer requirements, and developed partnerships to scale up their production tenfold with reduced waste and production time.  

There has been a societal push within the past three decades to introduce lightweight materials and decrease carbon and metal concentrations in coatings and elastomers. With the number of vehicles on the road and new regulations emphasizing lowering fuel consumption, CO2 emission, and product waste, the need for more environmentally friendly, economically viable compounds has been in constant discussion. PolyDrop tackled this issue through the introduction of conductive polymer-based materials into coatings and elastomers. Several applications were explored during the NSF Phase II project with the development of the minimum viable product for the silica-tire applications.  "Green tire formulations" compounds use silane-modified amorphous silica to increase tire performance which results in reduction of rolling resistance of the tire (up to 20% when compared to carbon black) and lower carbon dioxide emission (a quarter of a ton less for each car driving 50,000 km) while retaining optimal skid performance in the wet. Improvement of tire performance results in a 12% increase in fuel reduction per vehicle.  One fundamental limitation with silica is an unsettling compromise between conductivity, processability, and mechanical durability. PolyDrop team developed the silica/conductive polymer material that increases conductivity in elastomer, the processability of silica with a new one-pot synthesis process that reduced production waste ten times. During the NSF SBIR Phase II PolyDrop team was able to optimize conductive polymer/silica material with third party tire compounding and evaluation while designing a new scale-up process to increase yield/production costs. The minimum viable product was developed, and its target is to meet customer specifications for conductivity and allow for an easy one-step integration into production lines.  


Last Modified: 10/09/2019
Modified by: Volha Hrechka

The new additives are based on the synthesis of self-assembling nanostructure from conductive polymers and structure-directing agents. When successfully incorporated in elastomers, the conductive properties of elastomers are enhanced without compromising mechanical properties. In this Phase II effort, we optimized these additives, based on key customer requirements, and developed partnerships to scale up their production tenfold with reduced waste and production time. There has been a societal push within the past three decades to introduce lightweight materials and decrease carbon and metal concentrations in coatings and elastomers. With the number of vehicles on the road and new regulations emphasizing lowering fuel consumption, CO2 emission, and product waste, the need for more environmentally friendly, economically viable compounds has been in constant discussion. PolyDrop tackled this issue through the introduction of conductive polymer-based materials into coatings and elastomers. Several applications were explored during the NSF Phase II project with the development of the minimum viable product for the silica-tire applications. "Green tire formulations" compounds use silane-modified amorphous silica to increase tire performance which results in reduction of rolling resistance of the tire (up to 20% when compared to carbon black) and lower carbon dioxide emission (a quarter of a ton less for each car driving 50,000 km) while retaining optimal skid performance in the wet. Improvement of tire performance results in a 12% increase in fuel reduction per vehicle. The minimum viable product was developed, and its target is to meet customer specifications for conductivity and allow for an easy one-step integration into production lines.
